content: This week I was browsing the Micronaut Gitter channel and instantly got nerd snipped
description: This week I was browsing the Micronaut Gitter channel and instantly got nerd snipped
excerpt_html: This week I was browsing the Micronaut Gitter channel and instantly got nerd snipped
excerpt_text: This week I was browsing the Micronaut Gitter channel and instantly got nerd snipped
html: This week I was browsing the Micronaut Gitter channel and instantly got nerd snipped
summary:
This week I was browsing the Micronaut Gitter channel and saw a question about how to return a BufferedImage from a Micronaut controller. This isn’t something I’ve done before and it instantly nerd snipped me:
I am looking for help on how to make a controller method respond with a BufferedImage. Any ideas ?
I had a quick google, and it turns out you don’t need a buffered image at all.
title: Returning Images From Micronaut Controllers

content: There is a lot of admin involved in running a meetup group.  One of the things I wanted to automate was the creation of blog posts for our meetup blogs.  This post describes how I used Kotlin Script and JSoup to scrape the meetup page and create the blog posts.
description: There is a lot of admin involved in running a meetup group.  One of the things I wanted to automate was the creation of blog posts for our meetup blogs.  This post describes how I used Kotlin Script and JSoup to scrape the meetup page and create the blog posts.
excerpt_html: There is a lot of admin involved in running a meetup group.  One of the things I wanted to automate was the creation of blog posts for our meetup blogs.  This post describes how I used Kotlin Script and JSoup to scrape the meetup page and create the blog posts.
excerpt_text: There is a lot of admin involved in running a meetup group.  One of the things I wanted to automate was the creation of blog posts for our meetup blogs.  This post describes how I used Kotlin Script and JSoup to scrape the meetup page and create the blog posts.
html: There is a lot of admin involved in running a meetup group.  One of the things I wanted to automate was the creation of blog posts for our meetup blogs.  This post describes how I used Kotlin Script and JSoup to scrape the meetup page and create the blog posts.
summary:
The Dark Side of Running a Meetup Group I really enjoy running the Brighton Kotlin and Brighton JUG meetup groups. It is purely selfish to be honest, I get to meet lots of interesting people and learn a lot from the speakers and attendees and generally geek out with like-minded people.
However, there is a lot of admin involved in running a meetup group, let alone two - especially when you decide to set up a dedicated blog for each of the meetup groups.
title: Creating Hugo Blog Posts from Meetup Pages using Kotlin Script and JSoup

content: How to override a parent dependency in maven and use Snyk to validate
description: How to override a parent dependency in maven and use Snyk to validate
excerpt_html: How to override a parent dependency in maven and use Snyk to validate
excerpt_text: How to override a parent dependency in maven and use Snyk to validate
html: How to override a parent dependency in maven and use Snyk to validate
summary:
This weekend I am spending some time taking a look at my Snyk Dashboard and upgrading a few dependencies in old projects
The main thing I wanted to take a look at was the recent RCE (Remote Code Execution) vulnerability that was disclosed in the h2 database. This is a similar JNDI exploit to the one that impacted Log4j in December last year (called Log4Shell). You can read more about Log4Shell on the Snyk resources page and find details of the recent h2 RCE on the Snyk Vulnerability Database
title: Overriding a Parent Dependency in Maven

content: How to output the result of a mockmvc call to help with debugging
description: How to output the result of a mockmvc call to help with debugging
excerpt_html: How to output the result of a mockmvc call to help with debugging
excerpt_text: How to output the result of a mockmvc call to help with debugging
html: How to output the result of a mockmvc call to help with debugging
summary:
This post falls into the category of something I always forget and need to Google.
When running spring integration tests and using mockMvc, it can often be useful to see the output of the call in the console to help with debugging. This can be done by adding MockMvcResultsHandlers.print() to the call chain like in the following example.
This:
@Test void getStatementsThrowABadRequestWhenCookiesNotPresent() throws Exception { mockMvc.perform(get("/statements") .headers(getHeaders()) .cookie(getCookies()) .contentType(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)) .andExpect(status().isBadRequest()) .
title: Outputting the result of a mockMvc call

content: A hugo template to create Monzo style progression frameworks
description: A hugo template to create Monzo style progression frameworks
excerpt_html: A hugo template to create Monzo style progression frameworks
excerpt_text: A hugo template to create Monzo style progression frameworks
html: A hugo template to create Monzo style progression frameworks
summary:
I was introduced to progression frameworks last year when I came across the Monzo progression framework
I really like the idea that people within an organisation have a tool to help them grow and hone their strengths along with organisations ensuring they are in good shape, and their employees are happy.
The Monzo progression framework is built using the Gatsby static site builder which makes the frameworks easy to build and track via source control.
title: Creating a Progression Framework in Hugo

content: This implementation demonstrates a Junit 5 TestWatcher API implementation that hooks up your tests to a BlinkyTape LED strip.
description: This implementation demonstrates a Junit 5 TestWatcher API implementation that hooks up your tests to a BlinkyTape LED strip.
excerpt_html: This implementation demonstrates a Junit 5 TestWatcher API implementation that hooks up your tests to a BlinkyTape LED strip.
excerpt_text: This implementation demonstrates a Junit 5 TestWatcher API implementation that hooks up your tests to a BlinkyTape LED strip.
html: This implementation demonstrates a Junit 5 TestWatcher API implementation that hooks up your tests to a BlinkyTape LED strip.
summary:
Every so often I like to have a play around with a part of Junit that I haven’t used before, and I recently decided to look into the TestWatcher API.
I have to admit that I have been meaning to play with this for quite a while now…. I just haven’t really found a good use-case for it. Given that I decided to quit trying to find a good use-case and implement something nerdy instead.
title: BlinkyTape JUnit Testwatcher API Implementation

content: How many times do you need to use the name of the branch you are currently working on?  Up until now I didn't know an easy way to copy the name into the clipboard
description: How many times do you need to use the name of the branch you are currently working on?  Up until now I didn't know an easy way to copy the name into the clipboard
excerpt_html: How many times do you need to use the name of the branch you are currently working on?  Up until now I didn't know an easy way to copy the name into the clipboard
excerpt_text: How many times do you need to use the name of the branch you are currently working on?  Up until now I didn't know an easy way to copy the name into the clipboard
html: How many times do you need to use the name of the branch you are currently working on?  Up until now I didn't know an easy way to copy the name into the clipboard
summary:
How many times do you need to use the name of the branch you are currently working on ? Entering the name of the branch into your CI/CD system to deploy your feature branch into a staging environment, sending the name over email or internal messaging app to a co-worker who you are pair-programming with…
I seem to need to do this quite frequently over the course of a working week, and the place I always go to get the branch name is Intellij.
title: Copying A Branch Name In Intellij

content: I am loving the new JUnit 5 features and the @DisplayName annotation seemed like a great idea.  However, it was a lot of work to write and keep updated - especially when you like to write descriptive test method names.  It just seemed like unnecessary duplication.  With the latest JUnit 5.4 release and the new @DisplayNameGenerator API all of that will change.
description: I am loving the new JUnit 5 features and the @DisplayName annotation seemed like a great idea.  However, it was a lot of work to write and keep updated - especially when you like to write descriptive test method names.  It just seemed like unnecessary duplication.  With the latest JUnit 5.4 release and the new @DisplayNameGenerator API all of that will change.
excerpt_html: I am loving the new JUnit 5 features and the @DisplayName annotation seemed like a great idea.  However, it was a lot of work to write and keep updated - especially when you like to write descriptive test method names.  It just seemed like unnecessary duplication.  With the latest JUnit 5.4 release and the new @DisplayNameGenerator API all of that will change.
excerpt_text: I am loving the new JUnit 5 features and the @DisplayName annotation seemed like a great idea.  However, it was a lot of work to write and keep updated - especially when you like to write descriptive test method names.  It just seemed like unnecessary duplication.  With the latest JUnit 5.4 release and the new @DisplayNameGenerator API all of that will change.
html: I am loving the new JUnit 5 features and the @DisplayName annotation seemed like a great idea.  However, it was a lot of work to write and keep updated - especially when you like to write descriptive test method names.  It just seemed like unnecessary duplication.  With the latest JUnit 5.4 release and the new @DisplayNameGenerator API all of that will change.
summary:
I think it is fair to say that JUnit has been my go to unit testing framework for quite a while. I have used TestNG on some pretty major projects where it was already in use (and it has some awesome features) but if I am building something from scratch, I will most likely reach for the JUnit maven dependencies.
This was solidified even further with the release of JUnit 5.
title: Building a Camel Case @DisplayNameGenerator For JUnit 5

content: This post shows how I implemented a minimal test && commit || revert inside InelliJ - and when I say minimal I mean minimal.
description: This post shows how I implemented a minimal test && commit || revert inside InelliJ - and when I say minimal I mean minimal.
excerpt_html: This post shows how I implemented a minimal test && commit || revert inside InelliJ - and when I say minimal I mean minimal.
excerpt_text: This post shows how I implemented a minimal test && commit || revert inside InelliJ - and when I say minimal I mean minimal.
html: This post shows how I implemented a minimal test && commit || revert inside InelliJ - and when I say minimal I mean minimal.
summary:
Like many others, I have been reading about the new programming workflow introduced by Kent Beck called test && commit || revert (TCR)
When I first heard about it I had much the same response as Kent - why the hell would you want to do something like that? That can’t possibly work, my tests don’t always pass when I am experimenting - I would lose my code if I did this.
title: Tooling Up - Implementing test && commit || revert (TCR) In IntelliJ

That isn’t to say that it hasn’t been an extremely busy 2018. I just completely failed to write about any of it which is a shame. 2018 was filled with some pretty cool stuff:
title: Hello World.... erm again

content: ts been a while since I have completed one of the Oracle MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses).  This one on troubleshooting the JVM and OutOfMemoryErrors was particularly good.
description: ts been a while since I have completed one of the Oracle MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses).  This one on troubleshooting the JVM and OutOfMemoryErrors was particularly good.
excerpt_html: ts been a while since I have completed one of the Oracle MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses).  This one on troubleshooting the JVM and OutOfMemoryErrors was particularly good.
excerpt_text: ts been a while since I have completed one of the Oracle MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses).  This one on troubleshooting the JVM and OutOfMemoryErrors was particularly good.
html: ts been a while since I have completed one of the Oracle MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses).  This one on troubleshooting the JVM and OutOfMemoryErrors was particularly good.
summary:
Its been a while since I have completed one of the Oracle MOOC (Massive Open Online Courses). This one on troubleshooting the JVM and OutOfMemoryErrors was particularly good.
This Oracle MOOC was run by Poonam Parhar, currently a JVM Sustaining Engineer at Oracle where her primary responsibility is to resolve customer escalated problems against JRockit and HotSpot JVMs
Here is the summary from the course:
If you are interested in learning why our Java applications might exhibit performance problems, abnormal memory usage growth or sometimes even fail with OutOfMemoryError exceptions, and you want to learn how these problems can be diagnosed and eradicated, then this course is for you!
title: Oracle MOOC - Java Virtual Machine Troubleshooting (2018)

content: Listen to your code and evolve your design using TDD and auto running tests.
description: Listen to your code and evolve your design using TDD and auto running tests.
excerpt_html: Listen to your code and evolve your design using TDD and auto running tests.
excerpt_text: Listen to your code and evolve your design using TDD and auto running tests.
html: Listen to your code and evolve your design using TDD and auto running tests.
summary:
This is the first of my ‘reference’ posts which pretty much means I am writing about it here so I don’t forget about it in the future.
This post it about configuring your dev environment to provide you with continuous feedback while writing your code. All of this came about after a conversation with another developer on my team about how to setup IntelliJ to run tests automatically. We were looking at plugins such as Infinitest but it all seemed a little clunky and crashed every so often.
title: Continuous Feedback With TDD & Auto Running Tests

content: A quick discussion on the pros and cons of a static versus dynamic website.  I also give a little bit of an insight as to why I am using a static site and what I am using to bake it with.
description: A quick discussion on the pros and cons of a static versus dynamic website.  I also give a little bit of an insight as to why I am using a static site and what I am using to bake it with.
excerpt_html: A quick discussion on the pros and cons of a static versus dynamic website.  I also give a little bit of an insight as to why I am using a static site and what I am using to bake it with.
excerpt_text: A quick discussion on the pros and cons of a static versus dynamic website.  I also give a little bit of an insight as to why I am using a static site and what I am using to bake it with.
html: A quick discussion on the pros and cons of a static versus dynamic website.  I also give a little bit of an insight as to why I am using a static site and what I am using to bake it with.
summary:
Before I go much further, I thought it was probably worth me putting down a few notes about my technology choices for this site.
In term of website development, I have had experience of quite a few different content management systems such as b2Evolution and more recently Wordpress. I have developed plugins and templates for b2Evolution as well as contributing code to the core product back in the day. I have put more sites together in Wordpress than I care to remember - most of my clients used Wordpress in some form or other while I was working in the paid traffic/SEO industry.
title: Do You Bake or Fry

content: The customary first post.  Nothing much to see here..... move along :)
description: The customary first post.  Nothing much to see here..... move along :)
excerpt_html: The customary first post.  Nothing much to see here..... move along :)
excerpt_text: The customary first post.  Nothing much to see here..... move along :)
html: The customary first post.  Nothing much to see here..... move along :)
summary:
Well, it has been quite a while since I’ve had a personal site up and running but given I am back in the dev world full-time, now seemed like a good time to kick one off again.
At the moment I have no idea where this site is going to go but at the very least it will be a place for me to document what I am working on and the things I am playing around with - more for my reference than anything else but hopefully there might be some use for others as well.
title: Hello World

content: About Lee Turner
description: About Lee Turner
excerpt_html: About Lee Turner
excerpt_text: About Lee Turner
html: About Lee Turner
summary: I am an experienced software engineer with over 20 years experience working on large scale software implementations and have a passion for well crafted, pragmatically tested software. I am currently working at Crown Agents Bank as a Senior Software Engineer and have significant experience in Java, Kotlin and Spring Boot along with test-driven development and stringent source and release management processes. I am also experienced with agile practices such as scrum, pair programming and continuous integration.
title: About

summary:
Welcome to the Brighton Kotlin meetup group. I set up this group in 2019 for Kotlin users, enthusiasts and learners from beginners to experts, and anyone wanting to get involved with the Kotlin/JVM ecosystem in the local Brighton area. Due to COVID-19, we decided to move the meetups online in 2021 and are now enjoying speakers from further afield than Brighton which has been great for the local community.
We have regular meetups, presentations and talks, and are always interested in hearing what people want to know about, so please let us know.
title: Brighton Kotlin

Hugo Progression Framework Hugo Progression is a Hugo template that can render progression frameworks using the same data format as the Monzo progression framework - find out more information in this blog post

My Communities I currently run two local meetups in Brighton - Brighton Kotlin and Brighton JUG where we bring Kotlin and Java users, enthusiasts and learners from beginners to experts, and anyone wanting to get involved with the Kotlin/JVM ecosystem together to learn and support each other.
